title: Get Ready to Respond to a Job Offer

content.content:
The best time to prepare for a job offer is before it happens. It’s important to have a good sense of both the job market where you live, as well as your own priorities. 

By preparing ahead of time, you can make sure you have the information you need to decide whether or not an opportunity is right for you.

content.heading: When You First Get an Offer
content.subheading: When you first get an offer:
items: Ask for time to consider. You’ll want at least 2 or 3 days to think things over. Even if you’re sure you’ll accept, ask for the time just in case.
Thank the person for the opportunity, and let them know that you appreciate their interest in you.
Repeat back your understanding of the offer. This is a good way to make sure you’re on the same page, especially if you’ve received a verbal offer.

content.heading: To Negotiate an Offer
items: Make a case based on how you’ll contribute. If you think you’re worth more than the offer, build your case based on the value you can deliver. Don’t focus on why you need more to pay rent, bills, etc.

Find out where there’s wiggle room. Companies may offer perks that are negotiable even when salary isn’t. For example, you may be able to get more vacation time, tuition reimbursement, or a flexible schedule.

Know when to stop. If they’ve told you they’ve given you their best offer and it’s not one you can live with, it’s time to walk away. If it’s close enough to what you want, ask if you can meet to revisit your salary in a couple of months.

content.heading: Before You Accept
items: Understand the role and responsibilities. Review the job description again. If anything is still unclear, ask more questions.
Get the offer in writing. You don’t want to stop your job search — or quit your job — only to learn that the offer isn’t what you expected.

content.content: Below are 2 examples. The first is a specific response to an offer, and the second is a template you could adapt for yourself.

Thank you for sending over the job offer package for the Regional Sales Manager position. I am excited about the opportunity and would like to reiterate how grateful I am you’ve considered me for this role. I believe in your product and know I could help you drive even greater results.

However, before I accept your offer, I want to address the proposed salary.

As I shared during the interview process, I have more than twelve years’ experience in sales, including eight years of experience in medical equipment sales, and I have two more years of management experience than stated in the job description. In my last role, my team exceeded the monthly quota by 15% for two years in a row and landed three of the largest accounts in company history.

Given my experience and expertise, I am seeking a salary in the range of $75,000-80,000. However, I am open to discussing alternative compensation, such as opportunities for additional stock options or increased performance-based bonuses. (Source: Indeed.com)

Dear [Hiring manager],

I was thrilled to receive your email! Thank you so much for the [Position Title] opportunity.

Before I can formally accept the proposal, I need to discuss base salary. With my [2–3 industry-specific sources of value] and history of [summary of achievements], I know I will bring great value to [Company Name]. Because of my [experience/history] of [qualifications], I was really looking for an offer closer to [proposed salary].

I am still very excited about the offer, and would love to talk about the possibility of moving my starting wage closer to this number. I am open to bridging the pay gap through alternative means, such as [benefit #1] or [benefit #2] if necessary.

Regards,

[Your Name]
(Source: iHire.com)
Take a few minutes to fill in the information below. This will help you prioritize what you want in a job offer and put together a response like the examples above.

content.content:
Now that you have these key skills and accomplishments written down, practice saying them out loud. This will help you build confidence as you get ready for a job offer. 

If you’re applying for different types of positions, you may need to repeat parts of this exercise for each one.
